abstracts.cdata!:
This is a Project Performance Assessment
            Report (PPAR) on three projects for Cambodia: the Technical
            Assistance (TA) Project, the Structural Adjustment Credit
            (SAC), and the Demobilization and Reintegration Project
            (D&R). These projects are reviewed together because all
            three dealt with aspects of public sector financial
            management (PFM). However, the TA project and the SAC also
            addressed many other policy and institutional issues. All
            three projects suffered from flaws in project design and
            supervision, and weak government commitment to certain
            project objectives. The TA project and the D&R project
            outcomes were rated unsatisfactory in Implementation
            Completion Report (ICRs) and ICR reviews, and the SAC
            outcome was rated unsatisfactory, and the performance of the
            Bank and the Borrower was also rated moderately
            unsatisfactory for TA and SAC, and the performance of the
            Bank and the Borrower for D&R is rated moderately
            satisfactory. The lessons learned from the projects are: (i)
            a substantial share of donor aid to Cambodia has been
            allocated to TA, but results have been generally
            disappointing. Too much TA has been donor-driven without
            adequate Government involvement. This is changing in the
            Bank-led support for the Public Financial Management Reform
            Program (PFMRP); (ii) all three projects suffered from flaws
            in project design. The TA project and the SAC were overly
            broad in attempting to resolve too many problems through a
            single operation. The SAC had an excessive number of
            conditions which delayed effectiveness and tranche releases.
            The D&R project failed to heed the public complaints
            about falsification of the number of military personnel and
            corruption in handling the military payroll; (iii) the Bank
            was unrealistic in its assessment of the Government's
            commitment to many of the reforms in public administration
            and governance supported by these projects; (iv) the Bank
            should have carried out more intensive supervision of
            fiduciary issues in the International Development
            Association (IDA) portfolio. However, after the findings
            that led the Bank to declare misprocurement in the D&R
            project, the subsequent fiduciary review and the ensuing
            World Bank Department of Institutional Integrity (INT)
            investigations, the Bank has now taken appropriate steps to
            address these problems; and (v) the Bank delayed for almost
            ten years before building up an adequate field office
            presence, contrary to the lessons of experience in
            post-conflict countries. This had an adverse effect on the
            Bank's ability to supervise complex projects, to
            maintain regular contact with government officials, and to
            work effectively with other donors. This deficiency has been
            corrected since 2003.

display_title.display_title:
Cambodia - Technical Assistance
            Project; Structural Adjustment Credit; and Demobilization
            and Reintegration Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Demobilization and
            Reintegration Project in Cambodia was unsatisfactory, with
            an unlikely sustainability, negligible institutional
            development impact, and unsatisfactory performances by both
            the Bank and Borrower.  The Demobilization and Reintegration
            Project objectives were (i) to assist the Government in its
            effort to demobilize 30,000 soldiers and to promote their
            successful adaptation to civilian life; and (ii) to
            contribute to a reallocation of budgetary resources to the
            social sectors in order to build human, social and economic
            assets.  Lessons learned include: the issues which arose due
            to the political environment highlight the need for good and
            frank political analysis and assessment as part of project
            preparation; for the Bank to assist in developing better
            mechanisms of accountability in the government, makes sense
            from the perspective of internal governance, as well as
            ultimately helping to create a healthier environment; even
            in the absence of formal mechanisms in the country, the Bank
            and Implementing agency can do much to help build trust
            between all parties from the outset by agreeing on process
            and procedures to ensure transparency and encouraging broad
            participation from a range of stakeholders at all stages in
            the project; good knowledge and understanding of the
            military issues and objectives of military reform should be
            an essential element of designing demobilization;
            registration of soldiers needs to be carried out with
            extreme caution; demobilization projects need to be designed
            so that they do not increase incentives for soldiers to stay
            in the army in the hope of being included in a later stage,
            but progressively offer encouragement to leave for those
            that are no longer suitable to serve; increased monitoring
            of outputs on the ground, and greater inclusion of civil
            society and others in monitoring these outputs would be
            beneficial; legal agreements and Terms of Reference for
            consultants need to be carefully reviewed to ensure that
            there is no doubt as to the level of responsibility
            delegated to the consultants; strong leadership by Bank
            management in difficult cases is essential.
